question: Which surface feature is present on both the Earth and the Moon?

content.source_1: On Earth, tectonic faulting creates fault scarps—steep, linear cliffs where one block of crust has moved vertically relative to the other along a fault.
content.source_2: High-resolution Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter images have mapped hundreds of small, fresh-looking lobate thrust-fault scarps on the Moon, interpreted as tectonic cliffs formed as the Moon’s interior cooled and its crust contracted within the last ~50 million years.
content.source_3: The most prominent fault-related landforms on Earth (e.g., major mountain belts and long fault scarps) arise at active plate boundaries driven by plate tectonics.
content.source_4: The Moon lacks plate tectonics: it has no subduction zones, mid-ocean ridges, or long-lived system of moving lithospheric plates.
content.source_5: Many steep cliffs on Earth are shaped and maintained by erosion from rivers and wind, processes that depend on a substantial atmosphere and an active hydrologic cycle.
content.source_6: The Moon has essentially no atmosphere and no liquid surface water; its surface evolution is dominated by impact cratering and space weathering rather than erosion.
